title: 103_hr4758
content: The Act titled the "Durham Woods Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1994" increases inspection requirements in high-density population areas. The "Durham Woods Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1994" mandates increased inspection frequency for transmission pipelines, requiring operators to conduct aerial or ground inspections monthly to detect leaks. The "Durham Woods Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1994" requires operators to conduct monthly inspections to detect leaks and place line markers along transmission pipelines identified for safety reasons. SEC. 3. DAMAGE REPORTING. Amends the Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968 to require prompt reporting of damage to pipeline facilities. SEC. 4. INCREASED PENALTIES. Amends the Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968 to increase criminal penalties for violations, including raising imprisonment terms to up to 10 years and fines up to $100,000. The Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968 is amended to increase civil penalties, with fines now ranging from $50,000 to $1,000,000. SEC. 5 amends the Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968 to include grants for states to promote public awareness of dangers near gas pipelines. The Secretary of Transportation will conduct a study on the safety of natural gas transmission pipelines in New Jersey, addressing population encroachment, environmental concerns, financial pressures, and the feasibility of shut-off valves. A report will be submitted to Congress within one year. The Secretary of Transportation will assess risks related to natural gas transportation by pipeline, ranking them by probability and severity. Actions to reduce risks will be identified and prioritized, including inspection by internal devices, emergency flow restricting devices, and inspection of underwater pipelines. The Secretary of Transportation will assess risks related to natural gas transportation by pipeline, including inspection and burial of underwater pipelines, and inspection and replacement of cast iron pipelines. A report to Congress will be submitted within 18 months, outlining the assessment and proposed actions to address identified risks. SEC. 22. MAPPING. The National Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968 is amended to include a new section on mapping. The National Gas Pipeline Safety Act of 1968 is amended to include a new section on mapping. The owner or operator of transmission pipelines must inform the Secretary of their specific locations. The Secretary will develop a comprehensive mapping program to identify all transmission pipelines, including their proximity to high-density population areas and environmentally sensitive areas. The program will have an electronic database available to the public for security purposes. The Secretary must ensure the security of the program against terrorism, sabotage, and other threats.
